# problem 1
```{r}
set.seed(10)

iris_with_missing = iris %>% 
  map_df(~replace(.x, sample(1:150, 20), NA)) %>%
  mutate(Species = as.character(Species))
```

```{r}
fill_missing=function(x){
  
  if(is.numeric(x)){
    x[is.na(x)]=mean(x,na.rm=TRUE)
    
  }else if (!is.numeric(x)){
    x[is.na(x)]="virginica"
  }
  
  x
}
```

```{r}
output=map_dfr(iris_with_missing,fill_missing)
```


# problem 2
```{r}
filenames=list.files(path="./data")%>%
  substr(1,6)

df= tibble(
  filenames = list.files(path="./data"),
  path = str_c("./data/", filenames)
)%>%
  mutate(
    obs_time = map(path, read_csv),
  )%>%
  unnest()%>%
  select(-path)%>%
  mutate(
    arm = substr(filenames, 1, 3),
    arm = recode(arm, "con" = "control",
                      "exp" = "experiment"),
    subject_id=substr(filenames,5,6),
    subject_id=as.numeric(subject_id))%>%
  pivot_longer(
    week_1:week_8,
    names_to = "week",
    values_to = "obs"
  )%>%
  mutate(
    week=substr(week, 6,7),
    week=as.numeric(week)
  )%>%
  select(-filenames)
```

## spaghetti

```{r}
df%>%
  ggplot(aes(x = week, y = obs, group= subject_id,color=subject_id)）+
  geom_line() +facet_grid(. ~arm) +
   labs(
    title = "Observations on each subject over time",
    x = "week",
    y = "observations"
  ) 
```

comments:We can see an obvious increasing trend of values of observations over time in the experiment group.

# problem 3
```{r}
sim_regression = function(n=30, beta0 = 2, beta1 = 0，sigma=50) {
  
  sim_data = tibble(
    xi1 = rnorm(n, mean = 0, sd = 1),
    yi = beta0 + beta1 * x + rnorm(n, 0, 1)
  )
  
  ls_fit = lm(y ~ x, data = sim_data)
  
  tibble(
    beta0_hat = coef(ls_fit)[1],
    beta1_hat = coef(ls_fit)[2]
  )
}
```
